item.description: Before the game begins each player customizes several of the cards with names of family members, friends, pets etc. in Mad Libs Criss Cross Game. Then each player picks nine cards from the card tray and puts them onto their card holder (3 Nouns, 3 Verbs and 3 Misc.). The first player lays down a sentence made of cards and counts up the total score which is printed on the individual cards. The next player lays down a sentence crossing over or adding to the previous sentence and adds up the score. When all of the cards are used or no one else can make a sentence the game is over. Object of the Game: The player with the most points wins.

"The funny game of druggists" published by Julius Süss, Leipzig, Germany in 1920. It is the typical children's roll and move board game with interesting theme - children's games in pharmacy store. 
The goal of the game - to pass the pharmacy store first (pass the 110 stops).

Game board measures - 29 x 44 cm.

Designed by Jay and Susie Hernishin for their daughter, Fairy Mischief is a light game designed to help younger gamers transition into more advanced gaming with the goal of making more girl analog gamers!

Players take on the roles of fairies competing in displays of magic. The fairies will duel one another over colorful gem pieces that are randomly drawn from a satchel (watch out for the powerful black stones that grant special abilities). When one fairy has won a gem of each of the five colors, they win!

The basic game uses the classic game of War (players win duels by flipping over the top three cards of their deck and comparing who has the highest cards in a best-of-three fashion) combined with other elements to introduce the players to "gamery" skills (collection, special powers, and randomness).

There are also more advanced ways to play, so the game can grow with or adapt to kids. New concepts include (push-your-luck, hand ranks, informed guessing, discard pile awareness, etc.)

item.description:
Textra is word game, that consist of a plastic container, 206 letter tiles and 4 letter trays - clearly inspired by Scrabble, but the main gimmick here is the plastic container with clever mechanism to separate vowels and consonants. In the container you have trail where you put your letter tiles to make words. And when the trail is full (something like 15 tiles), the first used letters drop in to two departments one for vowels and other for consonants.

When you start the game, the first player puts one vowel and one consonant in any order in to the trail and then every player gets six letter tiles to make words. You can choose the distribution of vowels and consonants at the start of the game and always when you refill your tile tray. At the players turn you try to make a word using as many already laid letters in a trail as the first letters of your new word. Rest of your word consists of letters you have in your tray. You just put the letters from your tray to the trail to make a new word. Then you multiply newly added letters with letters you used from the previous ones and that makes your points. You fill your hand and then it is the next players turn.

Example: "AUTO" becomes "autoMATIC" (4*5=20 pts.), then "ticK" (3*1), then "tickLE" (4*2) etc.

In a four player game you play to the end of the round, when someone gets total of 60 points. Winner is the player who got the most points. In three player game you play until 80 points and with two players until 100 points. When playing alone you just decide number of rounds and try to make as many points as as you can.

You can play this game as long as you like, because the used letters are dropping back to containers departments, which is the same place where you take the new letter tiles. There is 100 vowel tiles and 100 consonant tiles and six wild tiles in the game. There's quite a few letters missing, that are used in Finnish language. Letter distribution of the game is: vowels: (40*A, 10*E, 20*I 15*O, 15*U) and consonants: (5*H, 5*J, 15*K, 15*L, 5*M, 10*N, 5*P, 5*R, 10*S, 20*T, 5*V). You can play the game in any language, where you can make enough words with these letters. Because of "the clever" mechanism, the vowel tiles are bit smaller than the consonant tiles.

name.value: Thüringer Land wie bist du schön

item.description:
Objective: be the first ending a round trip in Erfurt (Thuringia)
 - moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a marked space follow instructions...
remarks:
published ~1950's in the GDR

This is a very light (but difficult-to-master) dexterity game with collectable figurines made of a rubbery material. The game board is magnetic, and so is the bottom of every figure.

There are several modes of play, but all of them involve flicking your figurine(s), trying to get them to land on certain spots of the game board.

The figurines are mostly sold in single, blind-purchase booster packs (although there are some other packages available).

Objective: be the first ending a round trip in Berlin
 - moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game: choose one of the coloured routes around the world; ending on a marked space follow instructions...

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the winning French soccer team 2000

Boltâ€ˆAction: Assault on Normandy brings to you everything you need to pit your tactics and wits against your opponent as you recreate the great battles of World War II on the tabletop! In addition to the glorious Bolt Action rulebook and eight Orders Dice, you will find forty hard plastic, multi-pose 28mm miniatures as well as terrain for them to fight over. This is a great starting point as you seek to defeat your foes and bring an end to the greatest conflict in history.

This introductory boxed set includes miniatures from two factions – German and Americans – allowing two players to learn the basic rules of the game. Using miniature soldiers, tanks and terrain, you can fight battles in the shattered towns of occupied France, either liberating or holding the position according your faction. By moving miniatures that represent troops and vehicles (like Sherman tanks or half trucks) along a scenery-filled tabletop and using dice to resolve shooting or attacking actions as well as leadership tests, you attempt to finish the enemy army or achieve certain objectives.

Convert is a two player abstract strategy board game. Two opposing players each have a set of 10 differently shaped wooden blocks that are played on a 4x4 board with alternating black and white squares.

By manipulating pieces to fit on the board, as well as with each other, players attempt to score rows of four while claiming spaces on the board by converting them to their color.

When a player's piece completes a row of four squares, that player scores one point. When all pieces are played, or when neither player can play a piece, players add the points they scored during game-play to the amount of squares they have claimed on the board.

The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

New Second Edition rule set also applies to First (Kickstarter) Edition copies of Convert. New variant play modes, puzzles, and solo mode available. File available in the files section.

Microbadge

 Convert fan

item.description:
Educational board game for kindergartens about vegetables.

There is track on topside of the board and various vegetables growing on the game board under the track.
Player rolls the dice in his turn and moves accordingly on the track. If child lands on square where the name of vegetable is written he/she must recognize this vegetable from the board. Then he/she rolls again and the dice show one of the six categories player must answer the question about this vegetable.
If the answer is incorrect the player moves backward 3 squares.

Player who finishes first is the winner.

The game commences from the Sydney side of the Bridge marked Home and continues over the proposed scenic railway to the North Shore, and back along, the main roadway of the Bridge following the numbers from No. 1 to 100.
Each player throws the dice in turn it being necessary to throw a 6 to commence the journey.
The first player to return to Home wins the game.

Chains to Champions is a gladiator themed board game that consists of three phases. In phase one you purchase a gladiator at an auction, in phase two you equip your gladiator with weapons, helmets, armor, and training, and then in phase three all players fight to the death in the Arena. The last man standing wins!

From the back of the box: "Hurry, hurry! The auction is about to begin! There are many gladiators from which to choose. If you choose wisely, you could end up with riches beyond your wildest dreams. If you choose poorly, your gladiator may end up splattered on the sand of the arena. However, the strength behind the swing of his sword isn’t the only thing it takes to make your gladiator a champion. You’ll have access to the finest training and weapons that Rome has to offer before your gladiator is tossed into the arena for a merciless fight to arena in chains, but only one will emerge a champion.

Chains to Champions combines mathematical probability with human ingenuity to create a strategy game that is unique each time you play."
The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Quickfunds Dubai, a company located in Germany.

item.description: The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Key-Systems, a company located in Germany

Maximum Throwdown pits up to six players against one another in a battle royale of card-throwing action.

Each player has an individual deck of cards, and they take turns throwing the cards onto a shared playing area to try to cover up the icons of opponents' cards while keeping their own icons visible. On each turn, you draw one card from your deck and throw one card – but if you have the right icons in play, you'll draw more cards, throw more cards, steal cards from opponents and dump them in the gutter, break free of the shared playing space in order to keep from being covered, and – perhaps most important of all – score points each turn you have enough visible icons in play. After all the cards have been tossed, whoever has the most points wins!

item.description:
There's commotion in the village! The legendary Galipote, who, years ago, terrorized walkers in the west of France, has been seen at night, hidden behind the old oak tree : giant eyes, large jaws and big claws, of either green, yellow or red color.

At the beginning of each round, each player start with a hand of 7 Galipote cards.

During his turn, a player can places one of his card as Testimonial, on one of the 6 available sides, matching half-symbols and colors. If there is a Legend card available, he can places up to 2 cards according to the Legend. If he places a card with fur on the side, other players vote for the new Legend card. If he complete the Figure of Galipotes in one side (a symbol), he can score the cards for him.

The first player to get rid of all his cards, there is one turn until the end the game.

He scores as positive points all the remaining cards in players hand. Other players scores as negatives points all their cards in hand. All players scores as positive points the number of different colors of the Figure of Galipote, for each symbol.

item.description:
Objective: get most event/action cards; learn more about communication/environment; 
 - acting by turns/simultaneously -
shuffle 2 green, 4 red, 6 orange, 8 blue event/chance cards forming a pile;
create your world by assembling carton pads with a disc/placing 6 'weather' tiles upon the disc; at last fix all together with a rubber band building a tension
active player draws top card, depending on colour you have to solve a question (multiple choice), increase/decrease tension (rubber band), solve calamities (dropped weather tiles); if you are succeeding get corresponding event card...

Clacks: A Discworld Board Game is based on the "Clacks" semaphore messaging system — the fastest (non-magical) messaging system on the Discworld — featured in Sir Terry Pratchett's novel Going Postal.

Using a semaphore system of shuttered lamps on top of high towers, the Grand Trunk Semaphore Company has revolutionized long-distance communications on the Discworld. Their network of towers covers most of the Unnamed Continent, but now the old postal service is fighting back. Driven by the determination of newly "volunteered" Post Master Moist Von Lipwig, the Ankh-Morpork Post Office has challenged the Clacks operators to a race from Ankh-Morpork to Genua.

Play against your friends and claim the title of Fastest Clacks Operator on the line, or play together as a team to win the race across the Discworld and prove that Clacks is here to stay. In more detail, Clacks: A Discworld Board Game contains rules for a player vs. player game, a co-operative race game against the Post Office, and a children's introductory game.

A Decktet game for two players, in which you are a merchant attempting to claim as many trade routes throughout the kingdom as you can.

Ruta is a game of card drafting and network building, inspired by the popular game Ticket to Ride. A 5x3 grid of cards is used to represent the people and places with which players are trying to establish trade routes. Players take turns drawing cards and playing those cards to claim routes (orthogonal connections between adjacent cards on the map). Tokens are used to mark each player's routes.

Points are awarded for each route that is claimed, and players earn bonus points for their longest continuous route. When one player is out of tokens, the game ends, and the player with the most points wins.

This game requires a Decktet extended deck and 20 tokens in 2 colors (10 of each color). Suit chips may be used.

It’s an age of kings and kingdoms, heirs and assassinations. You and your opponents are vying for control over the four royal bloodlines. To emerge the victor, you must carefully manage a mismatched court of nobles to create the most prestigious kingdom the world has ever seen.

Bloodlines is a micro game using 20 playing cards and 5 cubes. Each player drafts a hand of cards, each of which has a special ability and a point value that contributes to your influence in that suit's bloodline. Once all cards have been played, the prestige of any lines you control is based on presence of cards of that type in your opponent’s kingdoms.

Each card you play has an associated special ability, and that card remains in your Kingdom as influence in that bloodline. The card abilities are:


 Ace (1 Influence): The Assassin may eliminate any unprotected card from the game, including any heirs placed on the card. 
 10 (2 Influence): The Castle protects all of the played cards in your kingdom from the effects of the Assassin and the Jack.
 Jack (3 Influence): The Jack may swap any two unprotected played cards of equal Influence value. You may swap for a lower valued card if swapping from your own kingdom. 
 Queen (4 Influence): The Queen may produce an heir on any card you have played, including herself and cards in Castles. The heir increases this cards influence in that bloodline by 1.
 King (5 Influence): The King has no ability, but he may be played directly into an empty Castle already in your Kingdom.


Full Rules available in the files section below

Simple board game for children about water safety.

Players roll the dice and move on the board. There are many special squares on the track to move forward or backward, miss the turn or answer the simple questions how to act safely near the water. Who finishes first is the winner.

Dating is hard in the 14th century, and as a matchmaker, business is slim. The plague has most folks too afraid to leave their homes, let alone go out looking for romance. Literacy is very low, so the letters you receive from clients are oftten difficult to make out. To make matters worse, you're not the only match-maker in town.

To come out on top of your rival matchmakers you will have to go with what little information you can decipher and find matches for your clients. At times it will be in your best interest you to work with your opponents, at others it will benefit you to set devious traps for them.

Love is in the air! But so is the plague...

In Black Plague Blind Date, players take turns choosing a card from their hands to play face down as a "blind date". They then must truthfully describe their card with 1-3 colored "info cubes" (blue = male, pink = female, black = infected, white = healthy, green = high class, brown = low class). Cards change hands during the exchange phase, then each player plays a second card face up next to any blind date. Blind dates are revealed and reputation points are scored based upon the best/worst dates. Matching two healthy townsfolk or two plague-ridden citizens will earn you points, but don't accidentally cross the two and spread the plague! The game is played over 4 "seasons" (rounds) with each season affecting scoring in a significant way. It's a quick-playing game of deduction and bluffing for 3-4 players.

Full rules are available under the Files section of this entry.


 Black Plague Blind Date won the February 2013 Boardroomers Game Design Contest in the 3+ Players category. Entrants in the contest were limited to using no more than 20 standard playing cards and 10 cubes.

item.description:
From the Website:

"Station Run is a board game version of the computer game Elite, released by Ian Bell and David Braben in the mid 80s.

You and some other players need to get from one end of the game board to the other without your ship being destroyed. Other players might do it, or some of the random people who ply the spacelanes might get to you first.

Station Run is a free-to-download game. No need to whip out the credit card for this one, and no need to try and remember your paypal password."

From the free PDF rules:

"Station Run is a game for one to four players. Each player is the pilot of a ship which has just hyperspaced into the system. They must get to the nearby planet’s space station in order to sell cargo, refuel or whatever else they might want to do. The player can take on a number of roles. Traders are ferrying cargo between systems to make profit, which they can use to improve their ship or buy another one. Bounty Hunters are seeking out wrongdoers and bringing them to justice. Pirates are only interested in plundering the traders and stealing their cargo. Miners are looking for asteroids to mine for valuable minerals.

The aim of the game is to get from one end of the game board to the other in one piece. Random encounters may occur, as other spacefarers and asteroids make their way around the planet’s
orbitspace. The game is designed to be open-ended and as freeform as possible (just like the computer game)."

High Heavens sets the players in the clouds, fighting for ultimate power above the earth.

High Heavens is a two player, tactical strategy game played on a hex grid, pitting Norse gods against Greek gods. The game is won when either all 12 gods in an entire pantheon is wiped out, or when Asgard or Mt. Olympus is destroyed. Players draw five cards every turn and then are allowed 3 actions. These actions can include Invoking a god, Moving, Attacking, playing a Divine Power card, using a god's Special Ability or Acquiring a dropped bonus chip. Red chips are stacked under each character to represent that characters health. Modifiers such as Attack Bonus, Armor, or Disabled are also represented by different colored chips. No two gods are alike, and their actions and abilities closely correlate to the mythology they were derived from. The luck of the cards you draw forces you to change your strategy from game to game. There is no reshuffling when you are out of cards, so once a god is dead, they're dead. Game play takes about a half an hour to an hour, depending on the players' skill, luck of the draw and the strategies used.

Created by award-winning video game industry veteran Ryan Lesser (Guitar Hero, Rock Band, Beatles:Rock Band, Dance Central...), High Heavens is a 2-player, expandable board game that utilizes lessons learned from 15 years of video game creation and a lifetime of playing board games.

item.description: Solar will attempt to usher in a new style of card games with its almost unheard of game mechanics. The game will start with both players choosing who picks the first character, that person starts on defense, the other play, on offense. Then, they both take turns choosing characters until they both have 12 card decks to play with. Each character shall feature its own art work and class, as well as one, two, or three attacks to use while on offense,and one or two defense moves while on defense. At the beginning of each turn, both players draw 3 characters from the top of the deck, and put one on the battlefield, and the other two on the bottom of his/her deck. Then, the player on offense may use his characters attack skills on his/her opponent's characters. If the hit lands successfully, the character is defeated. The game is over,and the winner decided, when one player has lost all of his characters and is labeled the loser.

The ancient manuscripts talk about a Leviathan, a huge creature lying on the silt bed of the lagoon on whose back the city has its foundations. All manuscripts agree on its eternal sleep and they all tell that the beast will wake up one day, shaking the city from its muddy roots, smashing the vitrified stilts on which the city stands, and crashing it into the seething sea where the monster will rise. The ancients say, however, that there will be signs; it is written that the Venetians will feel the tremors, that they would therefore save themselves from the monster, who will recover his freedom by plunging into the waves a deserted city.

But there were no signs. What ancients did not know is that the Leviathan is not alive. For centuries, the city lived and prospered on the back of a corpse. That corpse, though, is now awakening – and with it the dead arise from the lagoon...

In the cooperative game Carnival Zombie, players lead a group of characters who are fleeing on terra firma from the terror that has emerged from the lagoon of Venice. This group of characters must make its way through hordes of rotting "Infected" to leave the city, and players need to rush as the Leviathan upon which the foundations of Venice were built is awakening. Thus, it's only a matter of time before the city sinks in the dark waters of the lagoon.

Each game is divided into several nights and days. During the nights, players hide in trenches behind the barricades to resist the attacks of the Infected. During the day, players move through the city, which is shaken by tremors. The Infected are drawn by the groans of the Leviathan in the abyss to help their master free itself from the rotting stilts that nail it to the silt bed.

Players have several ways to get out of town, but little time to do it – and their path is hindered by the bosses, the most implacable servants of the Leviathan. If the players do make it out, they can assess their skills – and set a goal for next time – by counting the points scored during the game.

item.description: “Mijn eerste verkeersspel” (=My first road game) is a dice game for kids. The players have to walk from home to a particular purpose (e.g. school) on the other side of the road. The rules for pedestrian traffic have to be followed. Cars on the road can be moved by die roll. The game ends when all players have arrived at the goal. The main issue is finishing, although the player who finishes first wins. The game can be played with different rule variations.

A game about fishery. You go out by dice rolls with your diver and take chances fishing sea creatures for points - harder game is tricker to get and rare, easy game worth less points. Once everyone has gone around once and is back, the one with the most points wins.

-----

Um jogo sobre pescaria, onde cada jogador movimenta seus peões pelo tabuleiro, conforme os pontos obtidos nos dados. O objetivo é chegar à zonas de pesca, onde tentarão conquistar troféus e pontos em cada pescaria. Criaturas marinhas pescadas em profundidades maiores valem mais pontos. Vence o jogador que possuir mais pontos no final da partida.

Objective: be the first reaching space 50
 - moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game; endimg on a red space follow instructions glued on lid inside;
remarks:
probably published befor WWII

A two-player, print and play game designed for 2013 Two-Player Print-and-Play Design Contest.

Players take turns moving a pawn around London using tokens as action points. The Jekyll player is trying to discover the parts of a cure, to rid themselves of the Hyde personality. Hyde is trying to take full control of the pawn, by limiting the Jekyll players ability to use the tokens.

Most of the players' actions turn into a tug of war with the other player. Moving the pawn can place it in an advantageous location for the other player, and playing cards gives the other player a chance to draw them into their hand. Players must try to accomplish their goals without aiding their opponent.

The object of Speed is for the player to move his/her ship, plane, car and train along the designated routes from start to finish. The first player completing the routes for all four vehicles wins. Two to four players may play. There are 16 player pieces. One each of ship, plane, car and train in four colors (red, green, black and blue)

Movement is driven by card play. Each player selects four cards from the 40 card deck to start the game. Each player must maintain four cards in hand at all times. There are four "suites" (in red and black) corresponding to each of the four types of vehicles. The first player plays a card in the suite of his/her choice, announces the card and plays it face up. The player then draws from the deck to replenish the hand. The other players follow, and the player who played the highest value card in the suite lead gets to move the associated piece that number of spaces forward along the corresponding route. If a player does not have a card of the suite lead, they must play another card from another suite. The used cards are placed in a discard pile and shuffled if the draw pile is depleted.

The first player to reach the finish (Picnic Grounds) by any count wins the game. Two to four persons may play. Players take turns spinning and moving. If a player lands on a red colored space, the player must take a card and follow the printed instructions. There are 25 reward/penalty cards in a complete game. If the cards are exhausted during play they are reshuffled.

Game description from the publisher:

In Assassin's Creed: Arena – based on the Assassin's Creed video game series from Ubisoft – players compete to uncover the best targets for assassination, but before you can go in for the kill, sometimes you have to deal with pesky guards as well as your opponents. Players will collect cards and treasure, move guards, and hide within the city of Constantinople until they find their time to strike. Combat is handled through cardplay, and the player who best manages his cards will have the best chance at victory.

At the start of each player's turn, he draws an Event card, which can spawn new targets in the outer city, move guards, or allow you to find a tunnel to another section of the city. Moving guards is a great way to get them away from you and place them near your opponents. Targets cannot be assassinated while a guard is nearby, but fortunately the guards can be dispatched if need be.

Cards in hand drive the action, but they are also your hit points. If you run out of cards in hand, you die — but just like in a video game, you will soon respawn at your starting area. Moving and attacking targets (or your fellow players) requires playing cards, so doing too much all at once can be risky. Couple that with trying to avoid the guards and you are in for a tension-filled game of cat-and-mouse. To replenish your hand, complete objectives on your movement cards or hide. Hiding in the outer city is easy and grants you lots of extra cards. When you enter the merchant district or the area around the palace, there just aren’t as many places to hide and you will not draw many cards.

Combat is handled through cardplay. No dice are required, although a six-sided die is included to resolve some guard movement. Do you save your best cards for movement or to go in for the kill? He who risks the most has the chance for the most reward!

item.description:
The rain has stopped and the sun is out with a shining smile, but the beautiful rainbow is nowhere to be seen! It's all because those playful colors of the rainbow got distracted by the fun facilities in the park. They are running around and having a good time all over the park. Let's go find those colors and make the rainbow appear!

Contents: 54 game cards, including 49 Element cards and 5 pass cards.

This is a memory game where all of the cards are double-sided. Players take turns turning over cards to score matches. Players can collect pass cards and re-arrange the position of the game cards surrounding that card.

The game ends when the number of Element cards left on the playing surface is less than or equal to the number of the colors used to play the game. For example, if 5 colors were used to play the game, the game ends when there are 5 or fewer Element cards left on the playing surface.

At the end of the game, each player should add up the values of the cards he/she has collected: 1 point for each Element card, and 2 points for each Pass card. The highest scoring player wins the game.

Pogs are small cardboard disks with a variety of designs on them; they were popular in the early 90's. In the original game of Pogs, players would gamble Pogs from their own collection in an attempt to expand their collection further. Players would stack Pogs face down in a stack and throw a 'Kini' (a hard plastic disk, sometimes referred to as a 'Slammer') from above in an attempt to turn the Pogs over and claim them for their collection.

Pog word builder combines the classic action of Pog with the challenging gameplay of Scrabble. Use 1 letter and 2 letter Pogs to build the biggest words possible. Pog's are obtained in the same way as the original game, by by trying to turn over a stack of Pogs containing unknown letters. The player who builds the most words wins.

As the emphasis of Pog word builder is on the number of words, rather than the length or the quality of words, the game is easily accessible to young players.

Zippers is a fast paced communication quiz game. On the game cards are two sentences each, each one describing a different word. But the two sentences are, like a zipper, intertwined and at first make no sense. But if you look closely, you can possibly find out the answer. If you think you have the word, hit the reply card as soon as possible and receive the points.

item.description:
Memory Matching Mayhem

Players capture dinosaur cards by turning over a card in the battle card deck. In order to capture the dinosaur, the drawn battle card must be equal to or of a greater value than the now overturned dinosaur card.

When and if all the dinosaurs are successfully captured, the player with the greatest combined point value of all captured dinosaurs win.

Board game for local Estonian children game room.
Roll and move on the game board. Some special squares. Who finishes first is the winner.

Timeout is a trivia game with time pressure. Each player start with the same amount of time, and the faster you answer the faster you get to stop your clock. When running out of time you are out of the game.

When it's your turn, a trivia question is read out loud to you by an opponent and your time begins ticking. If you answer correctly, you get to stop the electronic clock, that's counting down. If you do not answer correctly (or don't answer at all) the clock counts down 20 seconds and the stops. 
The questions are divided into categories. Which category you get a question from depends on a die roll. Sometime you get to choose the category for yourself or for an opponent.
If a player fails to answer correctly, the next player has the chance to answer and thereby be rewarded with 10 bonus seconds. When out of time, a player is eliminated from the game.

Killer: Vanilla is a fast-paced card game with its tongue firmly in cheek. Players deal out death and destruction in many forms while trying to avoid the onslaught coming back at them. (This game is not recommended for children or those of a sensitive nature: bless 'em.) Kill off the weakest players to improve your hand as you balance defense and gear against a varied offense. Silent scoring heightens the tension... can you take another hit? Are Doctor De'Ath or the Booby Trap in someone's hand? Be the last man standing or take ‘em all with you!

Each turn a player may: make an Attack (Hand to Hand, Ranged, Area, Special) against any other player; play an Equipment card (aid survival); or change any or all cards in hand. Defense cards (Parry, Evade, Flee, Safe House, other) protect against Attacks, while Follow Ups boost damage. Global cards generally apply to all players. If a player gets a killing blow, his hand limit increases and he takes his target's cards. After the first kill, the scoring goes silent, leaving players with only an impression of how close to elimination they are.

Killer:Vanilla is a take-that card game which suits a 'beer & pretzels' mentality more than serious gaming. Play time is about 5 minutes per player, when you are used to the cards. The built-in expansion, The I In Team, adds some more complex solo cards as well as specific cards and rules for Team games.

item.description:
Suzerain combines elements of Deckbuilding with more traditional Trick Taking games. Throughout the game players will be playing to tricks in order to gain cards from the middle. After a trick the card gained, and the one used to gain it, will go into the player's discard pile. When a player plays their last card in hand their discard pile becomes their new hand and play continues.

Scoring is based upon sets of ranked cards as well as the Pawns and Courts which interact with certain ranked cards for bonus points.

This is a game for the Decktet; a deck with 6 suits and many double-suited cards. For more information on the decktet visit decktet.com or check out the BGG listing for Decktet.

In the game of Dragon Caster, you take on the role of a powerful sorcerer who fights other Casters for glory and conquest. Your casting numbers represent either the dragons you can summon to battle, or the type of mana that your dragons may obtain. This mana can be used to grant your dragons a variety of special powers. In order to gain victory, you must destroy the area containing your opponent's Caster.

This game was inspired from the game villages created by Jaron Frost.

Players play cards in groups of 3 cards to create levels, and may add more later on. Each card has a coin values. The first player who reaches 100 coins wins the game. Each turn players may attack a level of a player with one of their units to steal one of their cards. Each unit have a special ability that may affect their values during the game.

Cards are in French and English

A terrible thing is happening in a local village: Werewolves are responsible for the deaths of many villagers. Unable to determine who amongst themselves are werewolves, they've called in a group of master inquisitors to help sort out this mess before it's too late. That's where you and your team come in. No stranger to werewolf infestations, you know that the best thing to do is to start lynching suspects.

You no sooner get started on this project when you discover that there's a problem – Werewolves have also infiltrated your team of inquisitors! Now you're in a serious pickle: You need to save the village while thwarting the werewolves whom are working alongside you...

Ultimate Werewolf: Inquisition is a standalone game of deduction, secrets and betrayal with no elimination. Part of the fun is figuring out who the werewolves are on your team, but even then, you've still got to outsmart them!

More specifically, the humans need to rid the town of werewolves in order to win, while the werewolf players need to eliminate human villagers so that the werewolves can overrun the town. To do this, each round players either use the power of a villager's hut or take two votes from the supply. Each player then places one vote on a resident, and the resident with the most votes against him is lynched, with him and his hut being taken out of play. The werewolf players then secretly choose to kill a resident – but only one of those chosen by the Grand Inquisitor, a role that passes hands each round. Who will live? Who will die? It's in your hands...

item.description:
As the eastern bloc crumbles in 1989 Gorbatjov is ousted in a reactionary coup led by the Soviet military. In desperate attempt to turn back time and unite the eastern bloc the long prepared offensive into western Europe is launched. A critical element for success is to be able to interdict the American reinforcements over the Atlantic to its NATO allies. That job belongs to the submarines of the arctic fleet in Murmansk. But they need air support and support from surface vessels as well and Murmansk is too far away from the North Atlantic seas to provide that support. In order to seize air fields and naval bases on the Norwegian west coast as fast as possible an invasion of Finland and Sweden is launched at the same time as the Norwegian border is crossed on the Nordkapp to outflank the Norwegian easily defensible terrain along the northern coast. Neutrality will not protect Sweden this time. But maybe an army of 600 000 trained men and 600 tanks will?
This game deals with the southern part of the Soviet operation against Sweden, the invasion of Skåne. The well trained paratroopers of the VDV and the equally well trained Baltic marines land to face the bulk of the Swedish armoured brigades supported by infantry and artillery in terrain ideally suited for armoured units. Will the Swedish built turret less tank Strv 103 meet the expectations, though twenty years in service now, or will it be up to the British built Centurions, with more than thirty years in service, to destroy the invaders? 
With X pages of rules, XXX counters X maps and 13 scenarios the game is designed to help understanding of the challenges of the Swedes as well as those of the Warpac. While gameplay is designed to be fast and easy with command and control issues being in the centre of the design the optional rules allow for deeper study into logistics and recovery. Units are platoons and each game turn equals one hour . Hexes are 500 meters across.

Hit fast! Hit hard! centres on the 7th armoured brigade, PB7 Malmöbrigaden, and its hypothetical but well planned and trained actions around Ystad on the Scanian south coast. Equipped with Strv 103C, the upgraded version of the famous “S” tank was the cutting edge of the XI. Division responsible for repelling or at least fixing an invasion aimed at Ystad or Trelleborg. While PB7 might be superior in fire power to the air assault and naval infantry units it initially will encounter these are the elite units of the Soviet union. If the soviets seize a working harbour mechanised units with T-72M1 tanks are sure to pour in fast. You will also see parts of two different Swedish types of infantry brigades as well as territorial defence units and the 12th independent mechanised battalion with Strv 102R, partly upgraded Centurions, and motorised rifle companies in trucks rather than Pbv 302 infantry fighting vehicles.

"One against All" in English is a word game in which a player, in turn, plays against all others.

One player has 6 minutes to choose three secret words (maximum 10 letters per word), and gives a definition for these three words. The player draws half of the letter-cards for his opponents and gives information how many number of times this letter is present in the words etc. Player keeos other half of the cards.

When all the cards are drawn, the opponents have 6 minutes to find the words. For this, they can ask questions related to words, the player can only answer yes or no. Opponents can also ask if the letters kept by him during the draw are part of words.
The player receives tokens for each question or request letters, and receives a bonus for word not found.
The game is played over several rounds. The final winner is the one who has the most points.

PERFIDIOUS is a two player war game, set on a small map where two factions battle for control of the other’s Home Hex. All the armies in the game have their true strength hidden and battles are won based on the claims of the players (but the players can lie to win).

Players must use deceit to outwit their opponent and only by hiding your strengths and weaknesses will they succeed. But be careful; your opponent can call your bluffs and in doing so, may unravel your plans completely!

The base rules are simple and easy to learn but the game can be modified by a collection of optional rules to be mixed and matched at the start of the game by the players.

This game is also completely free to play and can be printed with any standard printer using 8½x11 paper. Some components require cutting so scissors are required for the initial building of the game.

This game is released under the Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 Unported

In CiRKiTRY, players have been invited to a local electronics competition. Your goal is to create a electronic circuit that uses all 5 of the following components: a Battery, a Resistor, an Inductor, a Capacitor, and an LED bulb. However, to make things more difficult, everyone will be competing on the same circuit board.

Players take turns uncovering circuit board tiles and placing their electronic components along the conductive paths. But be careful! The Voltage on the Volt-a-Meter fluctuates as components are played. If the Voltage gets raised too high, you might cause a destructive power surge.

Use Solder pieces to create pathways and make new connections. Not all 5 of the electronic components need to be your own, and you can attempt to piggyback off of your opponents' placement.

CiRKiTRY does not require prior knowledge of electronic engineering to play.

They came for our resources…
They came to annihilate us…
They came for our… cows?!

Welcome to Mars vs Earth! In this alternate-reality, 1950’s era setting – we are not alone! Aliens from the planet Mars have secretly descended upon Earth. As a member of an elite multi-national squad, you must defend our home against the vicious, little green men as they try to abduct our wives, mutilate our cows and boil our oceans!

To complicate matters (as if inside-out cows weren't bad enough), the aliens can replicate our DNA and clone human beings. They know our agency is the last line of defense and they have infiltrated our ranks. That trusted partner of yours may actually be an alien spy! Hey, I don’t remember you holding your hand over your heart during the National Anthem – when was the last time your DNA was screened?

About the game:

Mars vs. Earth is a simple card game, playable by 3 to 10 players in 30 to 60 minutes, that employs a modified "hidden loyalty" system. Mars vs. Earth introduces new mechanics, such as scaled martian powers and an accusation/trial system, that sit atop a wacky theme to increase play value and enjoyment.

Think your neighbor is secretly working against the agency? Keep him from leading missions, or better yet make a formal accusation and bring him to trial for his evil deeds! Of course you need to be careful - if you accidentally oust a true human from the agency they will become a lowly citizen with far fewer powers to help combat the martian threats!

The game is over when either the humans have foiled enough of the martians' plans or the martians have destroyed every last human resource, be it military defenses, tech, people or food. In either case, Mars vs. Earth is guaranteed to create some of the greatest play experiences imaginable!

item.description:
All your life all you've wanted was to have the best, the biggest, and the most awesome tick collection in the world. With You Suck, that dream is close to becoming a reality.

Using a suited deck, you and your opponents will play cards onto seven different ticks, each with a unique power. Take advantage of these powers to ensure that you'll match your bid and capture even more ticks. You'll score points for bidding correctly and for capturing special bonus point ticks!

That's right – it's a tick-taking game, a close cousin of "trick-taking" games, but oh-so-much better because it has cute ticks. And it's more fun.

item.description:
KiCKeT is a football simulation game based on tactical movement of miniatures. The game is played with the feet: miniatures movement, passes and shots on goal, goalkeeper defence are all performed with one foot.

The game is about to get published and several versions of the box are envisaged. The boxes only differ in terms of amount of components, i.e. the number miniatures and the addition or not of various accessories.

“Standard" components:
- 2 or 4 wooden miniature field players, 20 cm high
- 2 wooden miniature goalkeepers, 20 cm high
- 2 goals of adjustable size
- 1 small fake-leather ball, soft inflated (no risk of damage…)
- markers for field and goal area corners

The game is playable on many surfaces: grass, carpet, parquet floor (with the “socks” accessory), cement, even sand !

The number of miniatures should be adapted to the field size, e.g. 2x3 m with 2 field players and a goalkeeper, 4x6 m with 4 field players and a goalkeeper.

As for human players, they can of course play 1-on-1, but playing 2-on-2 works perfectly, and with more players also assuming more miniatures (and space) are available. An atmosphere of table football played with the feet, or of giant, say, 8-players football table.

Basic rules:
- players take turns, and have 2 actions per turn
- possible actions are: move a miniature, or play the ball; the ball can be played directly with the foot, or a miniature can be pushed such that it moves the ball
- to be allowed to kick the ball, it must first be under control: a miniature controls the ball if one foot cannot be inserted between the miniature and the ball
- a shot on goal can be taken at any time, if the ball is under control; the intention to shoot must be announced
- the opponent can defend his goal with one foot; his other foot must stay planted behind the goal
- any contact with another miniature is a foul, which ends the turn

Other simple and logical rules take care of particular circumstances, in order to keep the flow of the game going.

item.description:
Defeat your Pharaoh foe by being the first to place five pyramids in a row.

Game includes 24 plastic pyramids - 12 green and 12 blue. Players take turns placing a pyramid on the table. Pyramids must touch when they are placed. First player to get 5 in a row wins!

item.description:
Simple auction card game. Players have a money cards from 10 to 150 dollar bids, and two special cards "Sheikh" and "Forgery". They bid on paintings, the paintings bring victory points (4 to 15) and have a frame of color, if you collect three pictures of the same frame, yout get another 5 points. Forgery of "fake"

Gameplay is a blind auction. After considerm players scoring points for the picture and points beyond.

Theme of the game: the auction of paintings XIX - XX centuries.

"Kupi Slona" - translates "Do You Want to Buy an Elephant?". It is a version of a climbing game (a famous game mechanics).

See: Cheat

User Summary
Pyramid is a solitaire card game using a traditional deck of cards (no Jokers). 28 cards are arranged in a pyramid with cards below covering half of a card in a row above. The bottom row will consist of 7 cards, with the peak consisting of a single card.

The player works to remove all cards from the pyramid by making sets of two cards that add up to 13. Aces are worth 1, Jacks are 11, Queens 12, and Kings 13 (and can be removed individually).

The remaining cards make up the Stock, or draw pile, and can be used to make sets.

The game is over if no more sets can be removed from the board, and a score is given by the value of cards left in the pyramid. Thus, a perfect score is 0.

Join the galactic conflict by taking control of one of five factions in this customizable card game. Pick your strategy. You can choose to the Empire, those forces still united in uneasy alliance, or side with the rogue element, Warlord Darkon, and his stolen Imperial Technology. Become a member of the Bogathan Empire, hell-bent on making up for those centuries of denial and finally eradicating all the inferior life forms. Maybe you’ll join with the Merchant Coterie, banding up with other freighter captains, merchants, and mercenaries, while trying to fulfill your Black Market deals. Become a part of the Void, sentient battle computers that want nothing more than to continue to repair and expand, even at the expense of everything else in the galaxy.

Shattered Empires is an expandable card game where each player has their own customized deck of cards built around a chosen faction. Each deck contains a Base, which represents the player, then all the components necessary to build a fleet of ships and wage war in an effort to destroy all opposing bases.

Players take turns allocating their resources, building ships, acquiring more resources, then using those ships and resources to attack their opponents.

name.value: Happy Feet Two: Slippery Slopes Game

item.description: In Slippery Slopes, players attempt to be the first to move his or her penguin to the end space. After rolling a die, a player moves his or her token to the next space matching the color or design on the die. When landing on a Happy Feet space, the token slides down a snow hill and lands in a new space.

item.description:
A Sci-Fi twist where Allied forces battle to destroy a time-travel port that guarantees the survival of the enemy's supreme human race.

Time Soldiers is a turn-based game for 2 players (Axis & Allies) or two teams of up to 3 players each. Played on a board divided into 3 separate areas for temporal jumps (Giza, Egypt 2560 BC, Holy Roman Empire 1248 AD, and Central Europe 1945 AD), and 1 area where soldier reinforcements can be acquired by each team. Located in the center of the board is a time-travel port that transports soldiers through both time and space to engage in battles.

The primary object of the game for the Axis Powers is to finish their two-stage plot to rid the world of the human race in 1945, then time-travel to the future in 1946 to start a supreme human race. The primary object of the game for the Allies is to locate the time-travel port, battle Axis forces to gain control of it, and shut it down before the Axis Powers finish their two-stage plot. If either stage of the plot is finished, the dynamics of the game changes drastically with battles in both time and space.

Players control and move soldiers of different ranks and powers in an attempt to battle and control element cards used in the Axis Powers’ two-stage plot, with movement and battle results determined by dice rolls. There are multiple successful strategies that could be used to win, and both sides have an equal likelihood of winning.

Created by award-winning video game designer and artist Ray Shingler, utilizes lessons learned from a 15 year career in video game and virtual world user interaction.

A children's game from the Rupert Fun book, in 1988.

A parent should first write some short messages, each on a separate piece of paper and give one to each player. It is important that each message should be different and yet have the same number of letters in it, say fifteen.

The idea of the game is to see which player can first cross out all the letters of his message. To do this the players take turns to shut their eyes and put the point of a pencil on the checkered squares of the game. If the pencil lands on a picture, the player must say what the object is. For example, “D” for Dog. If “D” appears on the player’s paper it can be crossed off the message. Sometimes a player will be lucky enough to land on one of the squares which contain an alphabet letter (that too can be crossed off). Should the pencil land on a blank square, the player ends his turn. The games goes on in this way until one player has all the letters of his message crossed out.

Here are some examples of ready¬made 15-letter messages which the parent can use to start the game.
PLEASE COME TO TEA.
DO YOU LIKE MY TOYS?
MEET YOU TOMORROW.
I HAVE SOME SWEETS.

A Spanish-language card game that is a variant of Crazy Eights, based on the Dungeons & Dragons cartoon.

Each player is dealt four cards (or seven cards if there are only two players) with the remaining deck placed with the top card face-up beside it (if a five is revealed then it should be shuffled back into the deck and the next top card revealed instead). Players take turns placing one of their cards face-up on the revealed deck, matching either the number or colour of the previous card (e.g.: 3 matches 3 and red matches red). Fives are wild and the player placing it decides its colour and number. If a player has no cards that will match the current card or wild cards then he must draw another from the unrevealed deck until a legal play can be made, but if there are no remaining cards then he passes instead. The player to discard all his cards is the winner.

The deck's red suite is The Last Illusion episode, the green suite is The Traitor episode, the yellow suite is Day Of The Dungeon Master episode and the blue suite is The Treasure Of Tardos episode.

There are 32 playing cards plus a card explaining the rules.

The box's artwork is based on the box's artwork from Quest for the Dungeonmaster.

The goal of the game is to create a pattern of three pawns (in a row or with an "L" shape) as well as the symmetrical pattern along the diagonal of the board.

Pawn can be set at the square dictated by the dice, or moved one step to an adjacent square.

item.description:
Our ancestors invented a way to reduce the craving for playing football during the cold winter months. It was the year 1900. The game was coined “Gombfoci”, a rather self-explanatory term, which describes a game played with buttons from coats upon a kitchen table. It spread like wildfire and soon came to be well known in such far off lands as Spain, USA or Brazil. These people changed the rules and by this created a new game called “12 Touches”, which later became an even greater success than its predecessor. (Geraldo Cardoso Décourt’s, in 1928).

This game simulates football, the board it is a small football field and both players control a team of disks (or rings), and move them by flicking or pressing their edges, in order to hit a smaller disc (the ball) with them. The players need to score by moving the ball into the goal. 
A match takes 20 minutes divided in 2 halves of 10 minutes each.

The game is turn-based, only the sector ball rule will change this. A turn normally consists of moving one of your buttons. The buttons have to slide on the table, but not by pushing or pulling. They can be moved by flicking or by pressing by the finger. The buttons cannot be lifted up and put elsewhere, only after goals and before goal-kicks, free kicks, penalties or corner kicks.

Sectorball actually means a valid pass in the football game. If you move a button and the ball stops close enough (maximum one button size) to another button controlled by you, then you get another turn.

The game is also suitable for solo play. The player then controls both sides. In this can be simulating whole world championships.

Players can play single matches, tournament based matches, league or swiss system.

We are moving the two games in one box. Same board game, two approaches. East meets West on the same "soccer pitch": Sector Ball Table Football vs. 12 Touches Brazilian.

OPFOR Insurgency II is the new, solitaire version of the old OPFOR Insurgency series from Warcoach Games. The new version is not only solitaire but incorporates all the best features of the previous Insurgency versions.

In this version, you lay down a grid of cards representing various terrain in your command area. Underneath are secretly placed a variety of cards that could be decoys or real insurgency units of various sizes. One card is a HVT (High Value Target). You draw a random hand and have 3 turns to find and destroy the HVT using those resources. Your resources could include intel units to help you locate the HVT, combat units to destroy it or any insurgents, support units to add strength to your combat units, or local national units to help in both intel and combat.

Based on the best-selling Veto (second edition) CCG – the first and only Polish collectible card game – Veto: The Boardgame is set in the 17th century, the time of noblemen, winged hussars, court intrigues, and elections of the king. In this political game, which also includes voting mechanisms and resource management, players are trying to place their candidate on the Polish throne.

Myth is a fully co-operative fantasy game. Players take on the role of one of 5 different heroes working together to defeat the Darkness. Each hero has a different skill set which represented by a unique deck of cards. Players spend Action Points by using cards. Once a certain amount of Action Points have been spent the Darkness fights back by activating monster lairs, spawning monster captains and eventually the Boss.

A complete game in Myth is called a Story. Each Story is played over three Acts. Acts can be played sequentially, or can be split up over three different game sessions.

Players' avatars within a Story are called Heroes. Myth Heroes are clothed in immense power, able to reave all but the mightiest foes. However, this power must be balanced lest the Darkness take too much notice. Players must weigh their actions against the Threat each will bring, with the consequences of awakening more evil and bringing doom on the party's endeavors. And be careful they must, as the Darkness is formidable and eager to snatch glory from the valiant.

Heroes are controlled through an intuitive Hero Deck (videos for each Hero can be found in the Game Play Videos section below). Each deck plays uniquely and allows players more freedom of action and the ability to truly impact the Story each and every Act. Yet, cooperation is the key to victory and bloody fortune. Players must communicate, interact, and assist each other or surely the Darkness will cover all.

Myth is a fully cooperative game. There is no player controlling the Darkness. The Darkness is governed by a set of rules unique to each Boss Deck and is activated through Hero actions. If the Heroes get overzealous, then the Darkness pushes back by activating Lairs, spawning Captains, and punishing the Heroes with devious Events. If the Heroes take a more subtle approach, then the Darkness reacts by reducing the potential for treasure and rewards. Without the treasures and equipment to upgrade, the Heroes will find each Act more difficult and eventually fail. The dynamic nature of the Darkness really lends a more fluid feel to the Story. Players aren't being driven by properties out of their control, nor are they being shepherded by a person whose skill has a direct impact on the enjoyment of the game.

Myth is a fun fantasy romp where players feel truly heroic. In the playing of the game, the players are creating their own mythos. These stories are the ones carried away from the table, becoming myths themselves. And these are the myths, with friends and family, that we carry with us; telling and retelling our endeavors at the mead benches, earning treasured smiles and laughter.

item.description:
The Daedalus Sentence is a cooperative escape game that challenges players to use limited actions and effective communication in order to flee from their captors and escape a dangerous and ever-changing prison. Use your actions to explore your surroundings, overcome guards, or change the layout of the prison itself - just be careful that the moves you make to save yourself don't doom a teammate!

In the year 2083, an alien race known as the Loctae descended on planet Earth, killing billions and capturing and containing the few million that remained. The survivors were sent to locations throughout the galaxy, to work as slaves or as subjects for genetic experiments. The most infamous of these locations, known as the Hive, is a Loctae space station orbiting Ganymede. Here, prisoners are harvested for their genetic material, which is used by the Loctae to make genetic hybrids engineered for aptitude in any skill the Loctae require. A few have tried to escape, but none have succeeded. Those who are not lost in the station's labyrinthine halls are recaptured by the station's guards and then moved to the front of the list of those who are to be processed. The failed escapees blabber about the twisted and spliced creatures that roam the corridors of the maze, as if they were in the Labyrinth of King Minos. The remaining survivors now call their plight "The Daedalus Sentence", a grim tribute to the facility's designer.

As the months in The Hive wear on, fewer and fewer prisoners remain. Fearing their subjects would run out before their experiments were completed, the Loctae have confined the remaining prisoners in regenerative pods, so that the organs and marrow taken from the prisoners will regenerate with time. Though expensive, this set up was proving successful for the Loctae until a rogue meteor struck the station, damaging the ship's AI and releasing the bonds that kept the prisoners contained. Now the prisoners have a chance, likely the last one they'll ever have, to brave the halls of The Hive and escape to freedom.

The main feature of the game is its rotating board. The board has four rotating rings, with players starting in the center prison cells and making their way to the outer ring, where they must find the final exit to make their escape. When players start the game, the entire board will be hidden. As they move from the start location, they need to spend actions to flip over tiles in order to discover the layout of each ring. Their main objective is to find the gate to the next ring, but as they explore they will discover tiles both beneficial and perilous. The tiles may allow them to influence the movement of enemies or the maze itself, but they may also spawn additional enemies that will hunt for the players until subdued. If the players can make their way through all four rings, find the final exit, and escape together, they win!

Enemies will spawn throughout the course of the game, both as the result of exploring tiles and from drawn cards. Unlike many card-driven games however, the players have a glimpse into their future by way of the Theseus Device, which holds eight cards that determine how the rings and enemies will move in coming rounds. All eight cards start hidden, but through die rolls (and cards played from the hands of players in case of emergency), players see some of the cards to come. This allows for careful planning, as players try to anticipate how rings will line up in future rounds, as well as making sure they are not caught in the patrol of any passing enemies. When the game starts, only two cards will be activated per round, but as the players breach additional rings, the number of cards that will activate increases. When playing the recommended timed game difficulty enhancer, this leads to a frantic rush as players try to evade enemies and find the exit while planning ahead for the next activation sequence.

The Daedalus Sentence is designed to be played at a variety of difficulty levels, and players can mix-and-match the optional difficulty enhancers to achieve the perfect intensity level for their group. In addition to a four player co-op game, The Daedalus Sentence can also be played one-versus-all, with a player taking the role of the labyrinth and its minions.

item.description:
It is a survival horror dungeon crawl adventure. Each player takes on a role as a cliche movie trope and tries to survive and evening filled with Zombies, Vampires and Werewolves. Players must collect items, deal with their quirks and try not to turn into the monsters that they are running away from. Of course, if they do they will gladly turn and try to kill their former partners… gotta love contagious disease.

This is an action point based game where players move their characters toward the exit. Players must decide if they should search rooms for items, flee, or fight the monsters. Monsters move and attack based on specialized dice. As players take damage they become more likely to turn into a monster.

Players earn victory points by killing monsters, revealing rooms, and achieving objectives on their quirk cards. Players who have died still can earn victory points by killing other players.

KoryÅ is a game based on an uchronian and politico-steampunk universe.

Each turn, players simultaneously choose a family of politician from their hand, and play as many cards of this family as they have and wish to. Each family has a value ranging from 1 to 9, which indicates both the number of cards in the family and the number of victory points the player controlling this family will score at the end of the game.

A game lasts exactly eight turns, and on each turn a family grants its specific power to the player controlling it. Thus, efficient handling of these powers is the key to success! While their influence increases turn by turn due to the number of authorized cards in their council, the number of cards drawn each turn dwindles, making choices all the more difficult.

item.description:
Have you ever played the old bar game, "Bullsh!t"?

Mash PotatoS essentially is exactly that, but with potatoes instead of numbers.

A group of players sit around in a table with the deck in the middle. When it comes to their turn they draw a card and place it in the "bowl" claiming out loud what color the potato is. It then goes onto the next turn if no one yells "Mash!" accusing the played card's claim a lie.

If the accuser is right he would win; if not he would lose his next turn.

No matter what color the potato actually is, the same color can not be claimed twice in a row.

Objective: hit as many hoodlums as possible
 - acting by turns -
Kim and her friends are trying to hit rogues using a catapult - use box inside as target (zones are marked);
do not hit Ron - you will get a minus point; 
hitting the same target zone - no additional point;
first player achieving 20 points wins the game

Probably made to cash in on decimalisation of the currency in Britasin.

Each player gets a board, with spaces for coins that will complete your image of Mr. Money. There is no choice or skill. You roll the Deci-Dice (sic) and your roll result tells you which coin you may place on your card. Play continues until one player has a completed card and that player wins.

In this game, you have captured by the village and thrust into a pit, which is the home of a dragon. You must fight the dragon to be able to get out. You are fortunate to have been left with some items, but this dungeon crawl will be hard.

To start the game, you make your character, and then the dungeon.
On your turn, you move, you fight, you see.
Will you find vast treasure, and weapons of great strength? Or will you find monsters of hideous nature? Can you survive?

If you are playing 2 player:

You have been captured by the barbaric goblins, and thrust into a pit, known as the arena. In order to get out, you must kill the other player. No rules, no limits, just a brutal blood bath. Oh, and did I mention there are still other monsters in here? Have fun...

All mechanics are the same, except you must fight the other player. And if you leave an area, it gets reset next time you enter it, so there is all ways something new.

The game features of Toby Twirl and his chums. Toby Twirl was a Pig with human hands and feet and he appeared in books by Sheila Hodgetts between 1946 and 1958. His image was illustrated by Edward Jeffrey. This game is from one of hthe Toby Twirl Adventures books.

Rules
An exciting game for a number of players. Choose one player as Leader, the rest being Runners. Use a dice for scoring and counters or buttons for players. The Leader has first throw; a six entitles anyone to an extra throw. Don’t wait for a six to commence. If a Runner catches up to, or passes, the Leader, he or she wins and takes the place of the Leader next round. If the Leader reaches home without being caught he or she is the winner and the next player in turn is the Leader for the following round.

Modern War #9, Jan-Feb 2014

War by Television: If The US & NATO Had Invaded Serbia is a "what-if" simulation of the fighting that might have occurred across rump-Yugoslavia in the late summer or early autumn of 1999 if the Western alliance had decided on a ground war to settle the Kosovo crisis. WbT is a two-player wargame of low-to-intermediate complexity that posits this might-have-been war lasting about a month, about the maximum time before the invaders' diminishing supplies, and their loss of the political will necessary to continue the fighting, would force a truce if victory had not already been achieved in the field.

Each hexagon equals 7.5 miles (12 km.) from side to opposite side. Each game turn represents two days. The units of maneuver are mostly brigades and divisions-size groupings for the Serbians; each with about 2,000 to 5,000 men, and about 25 to 50 armored fighting vehicles in the tracked mechanized units. On the NATO side, units are divisions, corps and armies, each containing about 9,000 to 25,000 men and up to 350 or so armored fighting vehicles. The invaders' air supremacy is built into several aspects of the rules (such as the CRT) and therefore is not represented by separate aircraft unit-counters.

Word Whimsy is a party game that uses "prompt cards" to set the theme for each round, such as "Good Name for a Metal Band" or "Most Likely to Win in a Fight". Players then use word cards to build a title or phrase that fits the theme. One player is the judge and awards points to the best entry.

item.description: A two player strategy game of space combat. Players take turns acting out their orders from the previous turn and then writing secret orders for their next move. Players can gain varying amounts of knowledge about their opponents next move using their Interdictors to intercept enemy communications. Some notable elements of the game are the secret orders,the element of piece facing, and the interception of orders.

item.description:
In a two players game, the aim is to find the card hidden by your apponent according to its resemblance to your own cards in a minimum of turns.
Each player take a identical deck of card.
Each smiley on card offers 3 features: Head, eyes and mouth in 3 colors.
the first player choose a card from his deck. The second player other choose a card from his deck and show it to the 1st player. Then, 1st player with one of the three special cards show the second player the scale of resemblance between the chosen card and the hidden one: Thumb up, flat hand or thumb down
- Wingo Dingo Trio: test your reflexes.
Depending of the result, the 2nd player place the played cards on the row in front of the special card.
Then he propose a new card, and so on.
At the end, once the card has been discovered, players count cards placed in special cards rows and score the number of turn it took to discover the oponent card.

Cannon smoke drifts heavily across your bow, obscuring your view of the battle strewn across the seascape. Several ships are locked in a fight for naval supremacy. Sailors climb the rigging as you command your pilot to steer windward, taking the weather gage on the closest ship- gaining superior position. As your gunners open fire with cannon, you call out to your marines to prepare for boarding!

Scalawag! is a competitive card game for 3-8 players. Each player is the captain of their own warship with the goal of eliminating all other players (or teams during Allegiance Play). Game play consists of a player issuing one Captain’s Order each turn, generally allowing them to either gather additional Compass Points (the game currency) or spend Compass Points to attack their opponents.

Players support their Captain’s Orders by declaring Crew. As a player’s Crew Cards are kept hidden from others and bluffing is allowed, knowing when to bluff and when to call a bluff (by calling out Scalawag!) is an important element to successful play.
